title: Sign of Mahershalalhashbaz
shortSummary: Isaiah 8 reveals God's prophetic warning through the sign of Mahershalalhashbaz, symbolizing the swift judgment on Damascus and Samaria by Assyria. The chapter emphasizes trust in God alone, rejecting political alliances, and highlights the coming trials for Israel, while affirming God's presence as Immanuel.
timeline: c. 735 BC - During the Syro-Ephraimite War, shortly before the Assyrian invasion of Israel and Syria

keyCharacters.name: Isaiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet receiving God's instructions and visions, tasked with delivering warnings and signs to Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Mahershalalhashbaz
keyCharacters.description: The son of Isaiah and the prophetess, whose name means 'Speed the spoil, hasten the prey,' symbolizing imminent Assyrian conquest.

keyCharacters.name: Uriah the priest
keyCharacters.description: A faithful witness called by Isaiah to record the prophetic message.

keyCharacters.name: Zechariah son of Jeberechiah
keyCharacters.description: Another faithful witness who helps authenticate Isaiah’s prophetic writings.

keyCharacters.name: Rezin and Remaliah's son
keyCharacters.description: Kings of Syria (Rezin) and Israel (Remaliah’s son), whose alliance is rejected by God in favor of trust in Him.

definitions.definition: A symbolic name meaning 'Speed the spoil, hasten the prey,' representing the rapid Assyrian conquest of Israel and Syria.
A small, gentle stream near Jerusalem symbolizing God's peaceful provision and protection.
Meaning 'God with us,' a prophetic title signifying God's presence among His people.
Occult practitioners or mediums who communicate with the dead, condemned in Scripture.
A holy place of refuge and protection, here referring to God as a place of safety for His people.

outline.heading: The Sign of Mahershalalhashbaz
outline.description: God commands Isaiah to write the name Mahershalalhashbaz on a large scroll and gives him a son with this name as a prophetic sign of the imminent Assyrian conquest of Damascus and Samaria.

outline.heading: Rejection of Political Alliances
outline.description: God condemns Israel's reliance on foreign alliances with Syria and Israel's king, warning that Assyria will flood over the land like a powerful river, yet assures that God is with His people.

outline.heading: Instruction to Isaiah and the People
outline.description: Isaiah is instructed not to fear the conspiracies of the people but to fear and sanctify the Lord alone, who will be both a sanctuary and a stumbling stone to Israel.

outline.heading: The Testimony Sealed and Waiting on God
outline.description: Isaiah is told to preserve the prophetic testimony and wait patiently on the Lord, with his children serving as signs and wonders from God.

outline.heading: Warning Against Occult Practices and Future Judgment
outline.description: The people are warned not to seek guidance from mediums or familiar spirits but to rely on God's law and testimony; failure to do so will result in distress, darkness, and despair.

application: Trust in God alone rather than in political alliances or worldly solutions when facing trials.
Sanctify and revere the Lord as your refuge and fear Him above all earthly powers.
Avoid occult practices and seek guidance only from God's Word and His Spirit.
Wait patiently on the Lord in times of difficulty, confident that He is present and sovereign.

keyVerses.text: Take counsel together, and it shall come to nought; speak the word, and it shall not stand: for God is with us.
keyVerses.significance: This verse assures believers that human plans opposing God's will will fail because God is with His people.

keyVerses.text: Sanctify the LORD of hosts himself; and let him be your fear, and let him be your dread.
keyVerses.significance: It calls believers to reverence and fear God alone, establishing the foundation for true faith and obedience.

keyVerses.text: And he shall be for a sanctuary; but for a stone of stumbling and for a rock of offence to both the houses of Israel, for a gin and for a snare to the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the dual role of God as protector for the faithful and a stumbling block for the disobedient.

keyVerses.text: To the law and to the testimony: if they speak not according to this word, it is because there is no light in them.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the necessity of aligning all teaching and prophecy with Scripture as the true source of spiritual light.
